text:
That might work, or you could just connect your pc to your phone with a cord, put your phone in developer mode (by tapping build number under about like 7 times), then enable usb debug mode. That way, android studio should be able to see your phone and allow you to test with it.
\nThere are features that cannot always be demonstrated on emulators. Emulators do not display exactly like a phone will do.
otext: That might work, or you could just connect your pc to your phone with a cord, put your phone in developer mode (by tapping build number under about like 7 times), then enable usb debug mode. That way, android studio should be able to see your phone and allow you to test with it. \nThere are features that cannot always be demonstrated on emulators. Emulators do not display exactly like a phone will do.

otext: This kind of question is a difficult one. Do you know how to use images normally in your xml layouts or how to create image element on the fly and attach it to a view? text:
it depense. but you can go for either java or c#.
JAVA: bcos it runs on all operating systems and you may later consider going for android app development.
c#: run on window although have been ported to run on other operating system using xamarin, it can also be use to write android and ios app.

Both share the same structure (C like structure). When you know one, its easy to pick the other.
otext:
it depense. but you can go for either java or c#.
JAVA: bcos it runs on all operating systems and you may later consider going for android app development.
c#: run on window although have been ported to run on other operating system using xamarin, it can also be use to write android and ios app.

Both share the same structure (C like structure). When you know one, its easy to pick the other.
